content.question: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid, is in equilibrium with, C a O, solid, plus C O 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mtext>CaO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> When heated strongly, solid calcium carbonate decomposes to produce solid calcium oxide and carbon dioxide gas, as represented by the equation above. A <math alttext="2.0 mole"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed in a rigid <math alttext="100 decimal point liters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> reaction vessel from which all the air has been evacuated. The vessel is heated to <math alttext="898 degrees Celsius"><mstyle><mrow><mn>898</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at which time the pressure of <math alttext="C O 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the vessel is constant at <math alttext="1.00 atmosphere"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, while some <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> remains in the vessel. (a) Calculate the number of moles of <math alttext="C O 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> present in the vessel at equilibrium.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid, is in equilibrium with, C a O, solid, plus C O 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mtext>CaO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> When heated strongly, solid calcium carbonate decomposes to produce solid calcium oxide and carbon dioxide gas, as represented by the equation above. A <math alttext="2.0 mole"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed in a rigid <math alttext="100 decimal point liters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> reaction vessel from which all the air has been evacuated. The vessel is heated to <math alttext="898 degrees Celsius"><mstyle><mrow><mn>898</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at which time the pressure of <math alttext="C O 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the vessel is constant at <math alttext="1.00 atmosphere"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, while some <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> remains in the vessel. (a) Calculate the number of moles of <math alttext="C O 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> present in the vessel at equilibrium.

(b) Write the expression for <math alttext="K sub p"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the equilibrium constant for the reaction, and determine its value at <math alttext="898 degrees Celsius"><mstyle><mrow><mn>898</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) The experiment was repeated, but this time starting with a <math alttext="4.0 mole"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. On the following graph, draw a curve showing how the pressure of <math alttext="C O 2 gas"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> would change over time as the vessel is heated to <math alttext="898 degrees Celsius"><mstyle><mrow><mn>898</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and equilibrium is established.

skill.text: 3.A: Represent chemical phenomena using appropriate graphing techniques, including correct scale and units.
